REASON FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION AND UPDATE



Stolthaven Houston, Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan ("RMP") in December of 2020 as a result of planned changes involving Acrylonitrile handling in a new Covered Process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal. The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:



- Adding Acrylonitrile Transfers from Marine Vessels into a Rail Car, and subsequent transfers of the Acrylonitrile from the loaded Rail Car into ISO Tank Containers for shipment off-site.  Acrylonitrile represents a regulated toxic substance to be handled above the Threshold Quantity in a new covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  



- Updating the maximum on-site inventories for all RMP regulated chemicals handled at the facility, and  



- Various data element updates since the previous RMP certification.  





? 68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Stolthaven Houston, Inc. is committed to operating and maintaining our processes related to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  The facility uses a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees and assets, our industrial neighbors, and the citizens of the surrounding community.  This Executive Summary provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has designed and implemented, including:



- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by 40 CFR 68 that may be handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding Threshold Quantities.



- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs.



- A five-year history of significant accidental releases, if applicable, from processes covered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") RMP regulations.



- An overview of our

emergency response programs.



- An overview of completed and planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring, and



- Detailed information about our Risk Management Program.





? 68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Stolthaven Houston, Inc. owns and operates a bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 188 above-ground storage tanks that vary in capacity from 2,000-barrels up to 110,000-barrels, five truck loading/unloading racks (Truck Racks T-3, T-4, T-5, T-6, and T-8), four rail car loading/unloading racks (Rail Racks R-1, R-2, R-3, and R-5), one dedicated barge dock (Barge Dock-C), a finger pier jetty equipped with two separate marine vessel berths for handling barges and ships (Ship Dock 2/3), and a new jetty placed into service in October of 2019 also for handling barges and ships (Ship Dock 11).  A rail car cleaning and intermodal transfer station (Rail Rack R-4 and Truck Rack T-7) is also located within the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and a biological waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are operated on-site to reduce the impact of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's operations on the environment.



Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal by various modes of transportation cargo container including tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, rail tank cars, barges, and marine parcel tankers.  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequently transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transportation modes.  Stolthaven Houston, Inc. also performs direct product transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars with no intermediate storage in the facility's above-ground storage tanks.

Similarly, land-based intermodal ("IMO") transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. does not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control the disposition of the various bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.



The following chemicals handled at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. are identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause adverse off-site consequences in the event of a significant accidental release:



Regulated Toxic Substances Currently in Storage:



Toluene Diisocyanate ("TDI"), Mixed Isomers: Chemical Abstracts Service ("CAS") Number 26471-62-5

Vinyl Acetate Monomer ("VAM"): CAS Number 108-05-4





Regulated Toxic Substances Handled via Direct Transfers (Marine Vessels into Rail Cars):



Acrylonitrile:  CAS Number 107-13-1





Regulated Flammable and Toxic Substances Handled via Intermodal Transfers (Rail Cars into ISO Tank Containers):



Isopentane: CAS Number 78-78-4

Pentane Blends (Containing up to 95-Percent n-Pentane): CAS Number 109-66-0

Acrylonitrile:  CAS Number 107-13-1





TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulated substances at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. that are present on-site above their corresponding Threshold Quantities at all times.  Isopentane and Pentane Blends containing up to 95-percent n-Pentane are periodically transloaded directly from rail tank cars into ISO tank containers with no intermediate on-site storage, other than loaded rail cars received into the facility that are staged on the terminal's storage tracks prior to performing the transfer into empty ISO Tank Containers.  Similarly, Acrylonitrile may be received into the facility via marine vessel and transferred directly into a Rail Car; cargo in the loaded Acrylonitrile rail car is

subsequently transferred into empty ISO Tank Containers for shipment off-site.  Accordingly, Isopentane, n-Pentane, and Acrylonitrile are not always present above their respective Threshold Quantities at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  As such, the "Predictive Filing" option in Section 1 (Registration Information), Item 1.16, of this RMP is noted as "Y".   



Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures ("SOP") and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment during the storage and/or transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated substances.





TOLUENE DIISOCYANATE STORAGE AND TRANSFERS: PROCESS 1



Stolthaven Houston, Inc. currently stores TDI in one 30,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tank (Low-Pressure Storage Tank D30-10) and in two 15,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tanks (Low-Pressure Storage Tanks D15-19 and D15-22).  Tank D30-10, which represents the facility's largest volume of TDI held in a single storage vessel, has a maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 13-million pounds (1,291,497-gallons).  Tank D15-19 has a maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 6.4-million pounds (626,258-gallons), and Tank D15-22 has a maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 6.4-million pounds (625,944-gallons).  TDI is received into the facility via delivery by marine parcel tankers, tank trucks, and rail tank cars; TDI is shipped outbound from Stolthaven Houston, Inc. by rail tank cars and marine parcel tankers.  Periodic direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels into rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. with no intermediate product storage in the three referenced D-Tank Farm storage tanks.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has over 26-years experience in the safe storage and handling of TDI. 



As part of the changes associated with additional

TDI storage in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D15-19 (Stolthaven Houston's most recent TDI expansion project), significant modifications were performed such that TDI is handled safely and efficiently in this tank, including installing a liner on the storage tank's floor and shell, installing a pipeline constructed of 316L stainless steel from the storage tank to the existing marine dock line in D-Manifold used exclusively for TDI marine-based transfers, replacing all existing gate valves on the Tank D15-19 system with ball valves for ease of operation and automation capability using an actuator, installing a stainless-steel pump for TDI at Storage Tank D15-19, installing hot water external heating panels, a water tank, and associated heating panel supply/return lines for Storage Tank D15-19 while in TDI service, insulating Tank D15-19, installing internal eductors at the tank's recirculation line to improve product mixing, installing electric heat tracing and insulation on the tank's lateral pipeline to D-Manifold, installing a dehydrator on the tank's vacuum breaker to help prevent moisture from entering the vapor space should there be a loss of plant nitrogen, and installing a carbon adsorption canister on the Storage Tank D15-19 vapor line prior to TDI vapors entering the terminal's common Tank Farm Vent Flare vapor header to reduce the concentration of TDI in the vapor system.  Full automation for D-Tank Farm is expected by the end of 2020. 





ISOPENTANE & PENTANE BLEND INTERMODAL TRANSFERS: PROCESS 2



Isopentane and Pentane Blends containing up to 95-percent n-Pentane are periodically transloaded directly between rail tank cars spotted at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's Rail Rack R-2 into ISO tank containers located at Truck Rack T-6, with no intermediate product storage in any of the terminal's storage tanks.  Vapors generated during these intermittent transfer operations are directed to the Tank Farm Vent Flare for emission control.  Loaded rail cars are r

eceived into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and are held on the facility's storage tracks before being moved to Rail Rack R-2 to perform the product transfers into empty ISO Tank Containers that have been pre-purged with Nitrogen and spotted at Truck Rack T-6.  Note that after loading, the ISO Containers are secured, weighed, and immediately shipped off-site by tractor-trailer after the appropriate transportation paperwork is completed.  Maximum chemical inventories reported with this RMP for Isopentane and n-Pentane conservatively assume that six rail cars loaded with 31,500-gallons of each cargo are held simultaneously on the facility's storage tracks.  During calendar year 2019, 55-separate Isopentane IMO loading events were completed between Racks R-2 and T-6.  Note that the Pentane Blend IMO transfers and Isopentane IMO transfers use the same equipment and transfers spots.





VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS: PROCESS 3



Storage Tank P50-5 is an existing internal floating roof ("IFR") tank at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of 50,445-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16.6-million pounds (2,118,691-gallons).  Tank P50-5, which represents the facility's largest volume of VAM held in a single storage vessel, was placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is stored and subsequently shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers, and occasionally by barges, that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Ship Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges into rail tank cars with no intermediate product storage, and VAM slops can also be received into the terminal from marine vessels berthed at Stolthaven Houston's docks.  



In November of 2017 Stolthaven Houston placed IFR Storage Tank P50-4 into VAM servi

ce.  Tank P50-4 has a working capacity of 48,651-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16-million pounds (2,043,337-gallons).  As a result of the 2017 VAM storage project for Tank P50-4, piping modifications were completed in P-Manifold to connect the marine transfer system for Tank P50-4 into the existing Dock Line P-D3-78, which was already in place for Tank P50-5 and dedicated exclusively to VAM service.  A new VAM filter-pot was also installed adjacent to Storage Tank P50-4.  



Note that the 2017 Tank P50-4 VAM storage project did not change the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's worst-case release scenario for VAM, as the maximum quantity of this material held in any one tank did not increase. Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water if-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the the facility's flammable or combustible liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has over 11-years experience in the safe storage and handling of VAM. Stolthaven Houston plans to fully automate P-Tank Farm in the coming years.  





ACRYLONITRILE DIRECT & INTERMODAL TRANSFERS: PROCESS 4



In December of 2020 Stolthaven Houston proposes to add a new RMP covered process at the Terminal; the new process, which will be designated as Process 4, is for Acrylonitrile Transfer Operations. A parcel of Acrylonitrile will be transferred directly from a marine vessel berthed at Stolthaven Houston's Ship Dock 2/3 into a rail car spotted at the facility's Rail Rack R-3. After loading the rail car directly from the marine vessel, the car will be temporarily staged on the facility's storage tracks before being shifted inside the plant to the Terminal's Rail Car Cleaning a

nd Intermodal Transfer Rack R-4. Once the loaded Acrylonitrile rail car is spotted at Rack R-4, the contents of the rail car will be emptied into multiple ISO Tank Containers. After loading, the ISO Tank Containers will be secured, weighed, provided with the appropriate transportation paperwork, and then shipped immediately off-site by tractor-trailer, at which point the facility will not have Acrylonitrile on-site above the corresponding 20,000-pound Threshold Quantity. Note that after emptying the rail cars, Stolthaven Houston may then clean the cars containing only Acrylonitrile residue at the terminal's R-4 Rail Car Cleaning Rack. 



Additional safeguards to be implemented for Acrylonitrile handling operations include, but are not limited to: verification of appropriate inhibitor level in the liquid Acrylonitrile before the cargo direct transfer operation from ship-to-rail car commences, use of the buddy system during all Acrylonitrile transfer operations and equipment connections/disconnections, applying a nitrogen pre-purge to below 5-percent oxygen content inside the dock line, rail car, and ISO Tank Containers to provide an inert atmosphere in all applicable equipment that will handle Acrylonitrile, vapor control using a flare for all rail car and ISO Tank Container loading operations, overfill protection installed in all ISO Tank Containers prior to commencing Acrylonitrile loading, fitting all rail cars receiving Acrylonitrile with a magnetic gauge rod to assist with inventory verification, and using third-party surveyors to pull and retain any required Acrylonitrile samples.  



For the purpose of defining maximum chemical inventories noted in this RMP, the densities of all regulated substances at their lowest expected operating temperatures were chosen to provide conservative estimates for the maximum chemical quantities (in pounds) that may be on-site at one time.  For the Off-Site Consequence Analysis ("OCA") parameters, specifically the vapor pressu

res for each regulated substance, Stolthaven Houston applied the vapor pressures at maximum expected operating temperatures to provide the most conservative OCA modeling results.  



   

? 68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:



- Process Safety Information ("PSI")



- Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA")



- ISO 9001:2015 Certified Quality Management System ("QMS") for continuous process improvement



- Employee Training / LTM



- Mechanical Integrity Program



- Spill Containment and Countermeasures



- Management of Change ("MOC")



- Pre-Startup Safety Review ("PSSR")



- Vapor Control Systems



- Compliance Audits



- Formal Incident Investigation



- Employee Participation Program



- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits



- Departmental / Safety Meetings



- Trained Emergency Response Team ("ERT")



- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors



- Mutual Aid Membership



- Ongoing Automation Enhancements and Upgrades



The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent and respond, as needed, to any accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard these management systems set for the way we conduct business, and we have controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.





? 68.155(d):  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the preceding five years there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal that resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



All incidents at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our faci

lity's ISO Certified QMS to identify the root cause of the event, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.





? 68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Stolthaven Houston maintains a Facility Response Plan ("FRP") with the United States Coast Guard, Houston-Galveston Sector. Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training standards for effectively protecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Local Emergency Planning Committee ("LEPC").  Stolthaven Houston's hazardous chemical inventory report (i.e. Tier II report) is maintained current with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality ("TCEQ"), the North Channel LEPC, and the local Channelview, Texas Fire Department.  Stolthaven Houston, Inc. is also a member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid ("CIMA"), which can provide world-class, rapid response assistance in the event of an on-site emergency.    



An Emergency Action Plan ("EAP") is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personnel injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.   





? 68.155(f):  CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The following is a list of completed and planned/ongoing initiatives at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to assist in preventing and/or responding to accidental chemical releases, to protect company employees and the environment, and to effectively manage hazards present at the facility:



- As they are made available when empty and clean, storage tanks with the potential to store toxic and/or flammable

liquids are being equipped with quick-closing ball valves to replace existing gate valves as part of ongoing safety enhancements and automation efforts, which include status alarms displayed in the terminal's 24-hour Operations Control Room, automated tank overfill protection systems, and remotely actuated valve closures.  Complete automation of D-Tank Farm and associated systems is expected by the end of 2020.  Automation of P-Tank Farm and associated systems is currently expected by the end of 2024.  



- Automated end-of-line valves installed at Truck Racks, Rail Racks, and Marine Docks to assist in preventing overfills.  



- Double verification of all line and hose connections before commencing any product transfer operations to reduce the possibility of incorrect valve and/or hose alignment.



- Adding a concrete secondary containment floor and total organic carbon ("TOC") analyzer to the facility's A-Tank Farm.  A-Tank Farm is one of Stolthaven Houston's original Tank Farms, and was originally constructed with earthen secondary containment.  



- Continuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001:2015 Certified QMS.



- Employee Experienced Feedback Program.



- Fall protection added at transfer racks where trucks and ISO containers are loaded and unloaded.



- Two 753-horsepower fire-water pump driver emergency diesel engines added in 2019 at Ship Dock 11 for fire-fighting response.  



- Gas detection systems updated in 2020 to include 5-gas monitors with photo-ionization detectors ("PID").



- Fire-fighting equipment upgrades planned for 2021, including the purchase of a new Fire Truck and a utility terrain vehicle ("UTV") Quick Attack Unit.



Additional capital budget projects under consideration for future improvements to safety and emergency response at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. include additional surveillance cameras to be installed around the terminal's east expansion property, and adding concrete paving to four existing tank farms (B, F
, S, and Q) that currently have earthen floors to improve both secondary containment capability and surface working conditions for employees.
